comments.commentBody: Some blame the Senate for going into recess without approving Zika funding. And while that's correct, the real issue is that Republicans have refused to allow a bill to come to a floor vote that hasn't come with ridiculous riders like defunding parts of Obamacare or Planned Parenthood (and with weird pork barrel spending related to the continuing operation of military bases in certain states). The blame clearly rests with them. If they were serious about preventing a serious disease from causing birth defects (and non-negligible health problems for people actually affected by the virus), they would present a clean bill for a vote, and it would pass.

Youthful indiscretion? The guy with the fantastical story, who couldn't wait to share with NBC that he had a cocked gun placed tat his head was 32 years old.
32 years old! No, not a youthful indiscretion.

@Roy Boswell - You're making a lot of inaccurate assumptions. There are good jobs to get, but many younger people today seem to want a particular job at a particular salary, and see no point to taking anything else. And just because you believe that previous generations "always made a decent wage with benefits" doesn't make it true.  Employer healthcare didn't exist in the private sector for decades, just the union jobs had that perk. Most companies didn't offer pensions to anyone except the higher ups, and only started offering health insurance to attract better employees. And 401ks, a very imperfect and potentially unreliable retirement savings plan, are relatively recent (and crashed in 2008 wiping out years of savings/gains).  So don't go spouting broad generalities that are mostly inaccurate.
Am I missing something?

No room for due process Don? Innocence until shown otherwise? With all these conflicting versions that are being updated in real-time, you are absolutely sure of your rendition of the facts from your vantage point in California? Why assume the "official story" is the correct one? Officials have never lied or tried to cover something up?

Even "stupid" "self-entitled young men" can be innocent and are entitled to fair process.
Loch is not a kid. He's 32 years old.

If you are replying to my post Dan, I never used the term "kid." As to the phrase "young men," I was quoting back language that Don used in his original post.

Also, my post had to do with due process, which would also apply to someone who is 32 years old and "not a kid," wouldn't it?

I am ashamed of what these team members have done . They are at the Olympics to represent our country . I am also disturbed that those in charge of our Olympic team would allow them to leave the village , without chaperones in the wee hours to go get drunk at a party . Lochte's propensity for this kind of behavior was already well - known .

These self -entitled young men were so stupid as to think that they could use the gas station's rest room as non-paying customers arriving in a cab ( this isn't the US , guys ) and then to top it off , break down the door and damage God knows what else there . And then to make up a story about being robbed in the host country by the police with a cocked gun placed to your forehead !

I say ban them from further Olympic competition . We all do stupid stuff when we are young , but this is beyond the pale and they were entrusted to represent our country in the most prestigious sporting event in the world . They do not deserve to compete in another Olympics .

Dayan earned his hero status in the Sinai Campaign in 1956, in which he led the Israel Defense Forces. Umm...Ryan Lochte is 32...way past the age when his actions can be excused by chalking it up to "youthful indiscretion".

Forgive me, Ms Anderson, but these weather events have been on-going for millennia, and will be on-going for millennia to come.

You are, however, right to blame man, but you dwell on all of the wrong reasons in doing so.

Much of the problem arises, as it did in Katrina, from man's insistence on removing nature's natural mechanisms for dealing with such weather and in hardening the Mississippi River shorelines so that the massive amounts of water being poured on the region have nowhere to go but up and over...or through...the man-made barrier trying to keep the river "under control".

Nature's system of marshes and wetlands absorb millions on millions of cubic meters of water, preventing it from becoming a problem to populated areas.

And when people build, and continue to build, on lands that are susceptible to flooding, the problems only become exacerbated.

Don't you think it is time to stop beating the climate change drum when there are some significantly more telling reasons why these "events" are so devastating?

Or are you one of those that think man is immune from both Mother Nature and natural selection?
Most of the damage from Katrina was because the levee on Lake Pontchartrain busted. That was the reason so many people flooded. It wasn't the hurricane at all.

Liz Spayd, not long after you arrived there was a story about content. We were all disgusted at the idea that the NYTimes was not going to move its focus away from reporting.

Now, we are having a global cascade of extreme weather events like this, and I for one, who follow these things, watched it unfold before it happened.

One suspicion I have is that the costly consequences of ignoring climate change are not something that fits well with some of your premium advertisers and the climate change denial industry, though you do some good reporting there. But it's time to show the steady increasing drumbeat of ruined lives. Texas has been something else this year!

But the ongoing cascade of weather events, even setting aside the many eloquent people who rightly complain here, is news that is only going to get worse over time.

There really is no need for five new Trump stories every few days. I know I'm as bad as the rest in clicking on them, he's so appalling, but this really is news. It's lives, a lot of lives.

For a summary of this year's weather costs, have a look, scroll down a bit here:
https://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/warmest-julyand-warmest-mo...

I followed Haiyan at that site before during and after. And I knew about Katrina two days before it made landfall. It's not difficult. Climate is weather over time and space. If people had the evidence, they would gradually notice the connections.

shout out to you. Spot on.

What is in dispute was Lochte's original account, that a gun was held to his head, and that there were multiple men. Lochte lied. He changed his account; his original account that a gun was held to his head is now a proven lie. There is no excuse for that and we do not need vandals and liars representing our country.

I recommend you go to Saks fifth avenue drunk and break a door. I'm pretty sure some money will change hands and the security will be there and probably the police. Then you should leave and give an interview in national tv saying that your were robbed. Yeah! Seams legit.
He's 32, for crying out loud. Grow up. Learn to manage your alcohol. Don't go breaking stuff around and self declaring yourself a victim.

It is fascinating that so many on this thread are ready to throw our Olympians under the bus.  The only material fact in dispute here is whether money changed hands.  If it did, then Lochte's account of the robbery, while incomplete by omitting the athletes' transgressions at the gas station, is essentially accurate.  It has been confirmed that the swimmers were confronted by men dressed as police i.e., security guards who pulled a gun.  It's not far fetched to believe that they indicated they would let the guys go for a little cash.  That's called robbery, even in Brazil.  Why so much self-hate America?
The gas station employees don't care about the security cameras when there is money to be made by holding a gun on 4 tourists.

I think they should all also be banned, at least for a few years, if not permanently, from international competition, since they have disgraced their country by their ignorant and arrogant behavior toward another nation.
Actually, it's really common to have night guards in places that are open late in Brazil like gas stations or pharmacies.

Oh, wait, now "waving guns" is ridiculous?  I thought we were the nation of the 2nd Amendment.  Trump wants concealed carry everywhere in the U.S.  But in Brazil?  Not allowed, ridiculous.  The nerve of security guards - carrying guns, waving them at unarmed people - people who happened to break into a locked location.  Talk about double standards.
many US gas station attendants working late at night have guns (in some parts of the US the customers often carry guns) - gun laws are more restrictive in Rio than in a lot of the US.

A filling station protected by armed guards? Sounds expensive. Must be a place where Brazil's top tenth of a percent go to gas up. I'm sure a lot of U.S. gas station attendants would appreciate such protection.

Yes, the swimmers were drunk and acted like arrogant idiots.

But...private security waving guns at unarmed people at a retail location? That's an unfortunate custom. Lochte may have lied, but a lot about the Brazilian authorities' story stinks too.

Yes, completely serious. There is no reason to point a gun at visitors to your country who have not injured anyone. The armed robbery against US citizens, followed by a campaign of lies by the so-called "police" in Rio is a crime against Americans. Yes, the State Department should get involved. Clearly, no one is safe in a country where tourists are threatened at gunpoint and a "state" body covers it up. Smacks of the dictators regimes of the past - and why should the US maintain diplomatic relations with a corrupt nation that cannot keep anyone safe on its territory? Get a grip on reality - if you can.

What about this statement in the article: "Mr. Veloso, the police chief, said he could not rule out that there was an extortion attempt by the guards, whom he described as “public agents,” a term that can be used for police officers or other members of the public security forces. "

Interesting, last night I read a lot of posts on different sites defending these young men with people even saying we should nuke Brazil. People were SO sure these 'golden boys' were being persecuted and the Rio police were overreacting OR the police were corrupt. "What did they have to gain?" some asked. Covering up their criminal actions is the answer. Yes, they were obviously intoxicated. Yes, boys will be boys...but these aren't boys. They are men and they represent our country. The 'robbery' story would have made them heroes when they got home. Medals or not, they are an embarrassment and there is no excuse that anyone can make to mitigate their behavior. The lesson here is, while our first instincts are to defend our citizens in a strange land, sometimes their actions are indefensible.
I'd like to see them answer for any criminal charges that the Brazilian prosecutor thinks are appropriate.  Then we'd see some true courage and responsibility.

I love the olympics because they bring about so many revelations (and I am not talking about the games). It reveals how unprepared the IOC actually is. Just watch the foolish statement issued by their spokesman endorsing the bad behavior of the 4 athletes. It also reveals how terribly inferior Brazilians in general feel towards the rest of the world (especially towards the US). Brazilians feel they were always encroached upon by the ‘powerful’. Brazilians are probably not alone, and I would dare say that some African-Americans watching this might well feel a similar outrage: four successful white american males getting away with petty crime. Yep, it just happened again.

In another article I recently read in NYT the reporter ended by saying the olympic party cost a lot to the struggling Brazilian economy (I agree), and that the best thing people could do would be to enjoy it (I agree even more). The four swimmers surely took this advice over the top. Lochte went out of his way to give that daydreaming interview to NBC, where he incredibly fantasized about the would-be robbery (he is a fabulous storyteller - he surely fooled me with that one).

Its ridiculous to say they should be stripped of their medals,. But it would be good for everyone, especially for young american kids inspired by the accomplishments of these 4+ swimmers, if they publicly admitted their mistakes. And please don’t take too long, because I feel matters might get messier.

I totally agree. Athletes represent their countries at the Games during the official events, but on their free time, no. They are not diplomats, they are not ambassadors, they are not surrogates for diplomats either - they are just regular tourists. What is really sad is that the Brazilian police, embarrassed by seeing a security guard point a gun and get money from tourists on a tape viewed globally, tried to pretend that the athletes told lies - wow, what hubris!  As for Rio and Brazil - we've seen enough to be wise now, and will not ever go there for any reason. As Yoda might say, backfired it did!
The swimmers' vandalism is shown on security video at the gas station. The off-duty prison guards were hired by the gas station as security guards.

The US no longer has any basis for the arrogance of its foreign travellers--we don't make much of anything, nor create wonderful art and even the bloated military can't win wars against horribly undermanned armies like the Taliban, This culture and its supporting empire has gone of the rails quickly, with not much to read about in the history books,

The Olympics is entirely about idolizing the participants for their athletic accomplishments.  We might now see some sportsmanship from a few of them who engaged in criminal acts in Brazil.  Personally I'm not holding my breath.
Hmm. Are you sure you watched all the videos?

What strikes me about this article is that while the world is watching the Olympics and looking at these world class athletes as heroes, it can easily be overlooked that not all of these athletes are world class people.  Ryan Lochte and his teammates made fools of themselves by falsely claiming they were robbed at gunpoint.  Multiple videos from their entire night were made available and it became clear that the accusations were a lie.  This is disappointing because as I routed for Team USA in the swimming events I felt like I was almost a teammate of theirs.  That's the beauty of the Olympics.  Anyone from any of the representing countries can tune in and feel like they are part of the action.  The Olympics bring out the patriots in us Americans.  To see the men I routed for in the swimming pool turn out to make such poor decisions is disappointing.  If these swimmers make the Olympics in 2020 it will be hard to route for them.  This goes to show, athletes should not be idolized for athletic accomplishments.

It wasn't Brazilian authorities who blew this out of proportion. You expect them to go to national TV to lie about a crime, during an event like the Olympics when all the eyes are turned to that country and not get any attention? The police at first were investigating the robbery they claimed they went through. Then got to the bottom of the story. And still investigating. Grown men vandalize a gas station and go cry to the world saying they were robbed and it's the Brazilians who are the foolish babies? I don't think so.
